title: How to Inoculate Ectomycorrhizal Fungi

steps.headline: Recognise Mycorrhizal fungi.
steps.description: It is a fungi that grow in conjunction to plants in a symbiotic association where the fungi increase the plant's water and nutrient uptake and the plant supplies the fungi with carbon through their roots and mycelia (fungal roots).

steps.headline: Learn about Ectomycorrhizal fungi.
steps.description: Those are Mycorrhizal fungi that attach their own mycelia to the roots of the host plant using their Hartig Net  without invading the host plant's roots. Ectomycorrhizae are usually associated with woody plants, including trees such as fir, pine, beech, oak, and birch.

steps.headline: Observe Hartig Net.
steps.description: It is the net-like formation of long, branching fungal cells that connect to the host plant's roots.

steps.headline: Wait the good time.
steps.description: Timing is key. It is best to start this project when the ectomycorrhizal fungi have fruiting bodies (mushrooms) for identification purposes.

steps.headline: Go to a wooded area.
steps.description: Identify a tree or plant that commonly has ectomycorrhizal fungi associated with it. (If possible find one within the same genus or species as the plant you will transplant to in order to ensure success.)

steps.headline: Identify an ectomycorrhizal fungus.
steps.description: It should be associated with the tree or plant that you found in step one.

steps.headline: Dig near the fungus.
steps.description: Using your plastic spoon and fork, carefully dig around the fungus and approximately 8 inches (20.3 cm) down so that you can clearly see its mycelia.

steps.headline: Remove a small section of mycelia attaching the mushroom with the plant root.
steps.description: (The mycelia will grow back and produce another mushroom next year).

steps.headline: Place the section of mycelia in the halved container bottom.
steps.description: Surround it with a soil and compost mixture.

steps.headline: Continue to water.
steps.description: Check on the growth of mycelia daily for three weeks.

steps.headline: Transport the fungus.
steps.description: Once the ectomycorrhizal fungus is fully established it can be transported to its new host plant.

steps.headline: Continue checking.
steps.description: Make sure to continually check on the fungus during the first few weeks to ensure success.

text: Learning About Fungi Recognise Mycorrhizal fungi. It is a fungi that grow in conjunction to plants in a symbiotic association where the fungi increase the plant's water and nutrient uptake and the plant supplies the fungi with carbon through their roots and mycelia (fungal roots). Learn about Ectomycorrhizal fungi. Those are Mycorrhizal fungi that attach their own mycelia to the roots of the host plant using their Hartig Net  without invading the host plant's roots. Ectomycorrhizae are usually associated with woody plants, including trees such as fir, pine, beech, oak, and birch. Observe Hartig Net. It is the net-like formation of long, branching fungal cells that connect to the host plant's roots. Inoculating Wait the good time. Timing is key. It is best to start this project when the ectomycorrhizal fungi have fruiting bodies (mushrooms) for identification purposes. Go to a wooded area. Identify a tree or plant that commonly has ectomycorrhizal fungi associated with it. (If possible find one within the same genus or species as the plant you will transplant to in order to ensure success.) Identify an ectomycorrhizal fungus. It should be associated with the tree or plant that you found in step one. Dig near the fungus. Using your plastic spoon and fork, carefully dig around the fungus and approximately 8 inches (20.3 cm) down so that you can clearly see its mycelia. Remove a small section of mycelia attaching the mushroom with the plant root. (The mycelia will grow back and produce another mushroom next year). Place the section of mycelia in the halved container bottom. Surround it with a soil and compost mixture. Wet the soil mixture. Add more if necessary. Continue to water. Check on the growth of mycelia daily for three weeks. Transport the fungus. Once the ectomycorrhizal fungus is fully established it can be transported to its new host plant. Continue checking. Make sure to continually check on the fungus during the first few weeks to ensure success.
